But now these days are gone, I’m not so self assured
 Now I find I’ve changed my mind and opened up the doors

When John was younger he felt like he was very confident and could cope on his own. However, now he is a big rock star, he feels the pressure of his success and is now open to the idea of opening up to people.
John himself says that the song is autobiographical. He had this to say about it:

When Help! came out, I was actually crying out for help. Most people think it’s just a fast rock ‘n’ roll song. I didn’t realise it at the time; I just wrote the song because I was commissioned to write it for the movie. But later, I knew I really was crying out for help.

But every now and then I feel so insecure
 I know that I just need you like I’ve never done before

Lost in the rise to fame, the author is pleading with the object of his affection to center him on a spiritual level.  Lennon’s commitment to spiritual health is no secret to his fans,  a particular lyric found in “Across the Universe” being a prime example of his devotion.

Some believe this lyric is an instance of backmasking.  After it was rumored that Paul McCartney had passed away, fans began searching through the band’s catalog for clues regarding Paul’s death.  This lyric was one fans came across in their search.  Although it has nothing to do with anyone’s death, it’s interesting nonetheless.

BACKMASKED LYRIC:

Now he uses marijuana

(Help!) I need somebody
 (Help!) Not just anybody
 (Help!) You know I need someone
 (Help!)

Having entered a state of depression and disillusionment following such a rapid rise to fame, Lennon felt like he needed to be brought back down to Earth. Pete Shotton, Lennon’s childhood friend, claimed that these lines were written about him. Initially, Lennon’s handwritten lyrics for this line read: “I would appreciate you being ‘round.” The change to “do” switches the meaning entirely—it’s now an expression of thanks rather than a request.

The frequent use of multi-syllabic words—very unusual for pop music in 1965—was the result of teasing by music journalist Maureen Cleave, who gently mocked Lennon’s constant use of short words in his songwriting. Lennon responded by writing a song full of words like “independence,” “appreciate,” and “insecure.”

The closing lines to the chorus are also reminiscent of another Beatles number-one hit, “Please, Please Me”“—even being sung in a similar falsetto:

Come on (come on)
Come on (come on)
Please please me (oh yeah) like I please you…

When I was younger, so much younger than today
 I never needed anybody’s help in any way

The technique of counter melody used here is one of the early places in modern rock. Curiously, it had been used in a another British song issued a few weeks before help – The Fortunes' “You’ve Got Your Troubles I got Mine”.

When I was younger so much younger than today
 I never needed anybody’s help in any way
 But now these days are gone, I’m not so self assured
 Now I find I’ve changed my mind and opened up the doors

A Rolling Stone writer described this song as Lennon’s first crack into the shell he’d built to protect himself, finally letting his emotions out regarding his fears of their quick fame. “Help!” was said to mark an important milestone in Lennon’s writing style.

During a Rolling Stone interview, Lennon said this was one of the few ‘true’ songs he’d ever written:

They were the ones I really wrote from experience and not projecting myself into a situation and writing a nice story about it.
